results.title: Dorothy Hewett
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers III”.
Dorothy Hewett reflects on her life as a playwright, poet, author and teacher. Hewett grew up in Western Australia and has been a writer all her life. A political, social and sexual rebel, she has created work which has often been controversial for its frankness and for the power of her female central characters. In this 1991 interview, Hewett discusses the professional and personal relationships that have enriched her life and inspired her writing. She also speaks about ageing and her struggle to overcome the loss of physical power. Research and interview: James Murdoch.

results.title: La Mama
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on stage”.
Betty Burstall founded La Mama in Carlton, Melbourne, in 1967 as a venue for experimental theatre. During her nine years as Artistic Director, she encouraged playwrights, poets, actors and musicians to reject theatrical traditions and push the boundaries of performing art. La Mama is synonymous with the renaissance of Australian theatre. Playwrights such as Williamson, Buzo, Dickins, Romeril and Hibberd wrote about contemporary Australia. Actors rejected the formality of conventional theatre and developed a larrikin performance style which reflected a new awareness of cultural identity. In this engaging compilation film, Burstall, her successor Liz Jones, writers Barry Dickins and Jack Hibberd and performers Petter Cummins and Valerie Kirwin speak to Mary-Lou Jelbart about the challenges and joys of working at La Mama.

results.title: Peter Sculthorpe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on music”.
Peter Sculthorpe, Australia’s best-known contemporary composer, discusses his personal philosophy and the influences which have shaped his creative development. Sculthorpe studied at the Melbourne University Conservatorium of Music and at Oxford University. His “Sonatina for Piano” was performed at the International Society of Contemporary Music Festival in Baden-Baden in 1955 and he went on to receive international recognition with the success of his Sun Music series. Throughout his career, Sculthorpe has drawn on a diversity of cultural influences in his quest to develop uniquely Australian music. He has composed for film, television, theatre and opera as well as the concert platform, and enjoys the status of elder statesman among contemporary Australian composers. A performance of his work “Kakadu” in 1989 was a rallying point for Australian conservationists and since then Sculthorpe has used his music to promote environmental causes. Research and interview: James Murdoch.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: on music

results.title: Alice Moyle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on music”.
Alice Moyle was born in South Africa on 25th December 1908 and spent her first four years there before migrating out to Australia with her parents. She learned the piano and studied music at school, attending the University of Melbourne Conservatorium where she graduated with a Bachelor of Music in 1930. Alice Moyle’s first experience of Aboriginal music was listening to recordings made by Professor Elkin when she was attending courses at the Faculty of Music at Sydney University. These recordings were to prepare teachers for work in the outback. In 1959 Alice made the first of many field trips into the outback to continue the process of recording and archiving Aboriginal music. She has continually tried to inspire others with her experiences and knowledge in Aboriginal music and culture and is adamant that music be included as an essential component in the study of Aboriginal culture. This documentary is a recorded interview between Alice Moyle and James Murdoch.

results.title: Buck Rogers. Vol. 5
results.creator_credit: Phil Leacock, Dick Lowry, David J. O'Connell, Jock Gaynor and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Buck Rogers in the 25th century”.
In ‘Unchained woman’, The Earth Defense Directorate send Buck and Wilma on a mission to rescue Jen Burton, the partner of notorious shipping pirate Malary Pantera, from a state-of-the-art underground jail where she has been incarcerated for a murder that Pantera actually committed. Masquerading as a convict, Buck infiltrates the high-tech facility, detonates a bomb, and they break out, heading to a nearby spaceport to meet Wilma and return to Earth. However, an android prison guard damaged during the explosion begins a relentless pursuit of them, determined to uphold the law. Their situation is complicated further when a traitorous ambassador informs Malary of Jen’s escape and the Earth Directorate’s plans to use her to gain information that will ultimately lead to his arrest. It is up to Buck and Wilma to both defeat him and shut down the obsessed android before Jen is silenced forever. In ‘Planet of the Amazon women’, Buck is lured to the planet Zantia after answering a distress call from two women whose space yacht is malfunctioning. Once on the planet’s surface, he learns that there is a shortage of men on Zantia, and that he is to be sold off to the highest bidder at an auction. Purchased by the Prime Minister’s daughter Ariela, he is surprised when he discovers what her true intentions are. With Wilma leaving delicate trade negotiations to go in search of her missing friend, it is up to Buck and Ariela to overthrow her mother’s oppressive government and liberate the planet’s male population from their captors before they declare another war on Zantia. Stars Gil Gerard as Buck, Erin Gray as Col. Deering, and Tim O’Connor as Dr. Huer. Special guest Jamie Lee Curtis stars as Jen Burton in ‘Unchained woman’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phil Leacock, Dick Lowry, David J. O’Connell, Jock Gaynor and Universal Pictures

results.title: Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description: A five part series which analyses the Australian Constitution and its prospects for change in the 21st century. The programs discuss a variety of issues related to the Australian constitution, with each focusing on specific subjects that define the content of the interviews with and commentary from politicians, academics, media commentators and legal counsel that make up each episode. The subjects covered by the series include the history of the Australian Constitution and its founding ideals, the possible make up of an Australian Republic and the necessary adaptations to the Constitution, the Australian Parliament and the Executive as well as their distribution of powers, the rights and guarantees contained in the Constitution for the community, issues of aboriginal reconciliation in the Constitution and the future of the Constitution through the political channels for change such as referendums.

results.title: Constitutional futures (A)
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The final episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the potential future of the Constitution and the facilities in the current political system that could be employed to institute change. Through commentary from a range of contributors a variety of subjects are discussed including Section 128 of the Australian Constitution, the notion of a citizens referenda and how the community can relate to and have power in the alteration of the Constitution. These contributors include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Michael Coper, Dr Helen Irving, Noel Pearson, Sir Zelman Cowan QC and Sir Anthony Mason.
